reviewText:
This is a fun game. It's a combination shooter and platformer with really high energy. The story is minimal, and the soundtrack is rather repetitive, but overall, the game has got some really entertaining qualities. The controls are consistently responsive, but it was a bit awkward for me to get used to using the D-Pad and not be able to use the left joystick for movement. The scavenger hunt for weapons and upgrades is definitely a plus and enough to keep most players entertained.

There are a lot of levels, but I didn't notice anything spectacular in regard to level design. Most new levels were variations of others, but the introduction of new monsters and weapons meant that this didn't detract from my gameplay.

It's definitely rough around the edges in some ways, though. I'm the type of gamer who is busting every destructible and searching for every possible hidden area and surprise. In doing this, I found an oddity very early on. Upon entering the first doorway (level) I jumped up to the platform on the upper left and started hopping around to see what was there. In attempting to see if my character could walljump, she fell" through what should have been a solid barrier all the way through to the previous area. When I walked back through the door
date: my progress had been reset as if I'd restarted the level. This oddity was easily repeated a number of times
recommended: but I could find no real purpose for it
hoursPlayed: so I was forced to conclude that it's simply a design flaw. I also noticed a placement issue
voteText: which was most noticeable to me on the second map. There are a certain amount of destructibles that can yield coins or hearts which grant healing. I found one of these green plant destructibles placed above a doorway to the left of the shop. However
helpfulPercent: it's impossible to get the heart that was dropping from this destructible. It seems to go either behind or through the doorway
votesHelpful: and getting too close to the doorway takes you back a level
votesTotal: where there was no heart waiting.\n\nOverall
votesFunny: this game has a lot to enjoy. It should appeal very easily to casual gamers
commentsCount: as well as fans of shooters

column18: meaning that you only have one life and that while you might have to go back a few levels

column20: it's very much like Giana Sisters: Twisted Dreams. The addition of a consumable lightpost also helps to reduce rage and allow even young and new gamers to enjoy it. Though I would encourage the developers to revise the store interface so that it's clear that the lightpost is indeed a consumable. I definitely recommend giving it a try.\n\nEdit: Just wanted to add that the level design gets more interesting as the game progresses

reviewText:
Cally’s Caves 3 is an action platformer with a Ratchet & Clank-style weapon upgrade system, and a karate master bear cub sidekick.
tl;dr It's a lot of fun with only superficial gripes. It focuses on gameplay far more than story as well.

The good:
This game oozes with style and takes good game design from some of my favourite Ratchet & Clank games.
The music is bumping with energy
The characters are cute and look good
It's has an interesting combination of level design and the combat system thats lend to natural advantages and disadvantages for the player or enemies. EG: The heights of platforms, sizes of enemies, positioning of everything.
Any early complaints I had with the game were quickly solved as you gain EXP, level up your weapons and generally get better at the game.
Learning the mechanics as you go makes a huge difference and the game doesn't baby you with tutorials.
That said it does a good job of encouraging you to learn the mechanics naturally through level design than obtuse or forced tutorials.
There are a ton of weapons and abilities.
Weapons can be upgraded a LOT through using them and they become really, really cool. Very R&C.
There are also weapon modifications although costly so will take some time to get.
The game does give hints towards mechanics that you have previously had chances to figure out, in case you didn't by yourself it will tell you not too much later. EG: Parry mechanics.
Options menus are good enough without complaint.
Lots of control options and remap the keybindings even for your controller if you use one.

The cons:
Music feels a little repeative at times but you can
Damage on touch with enemies can be annoying at times
Many weapons have a random spread instead of fixed-spread, may not be a con but it can make choosing a reliable weapon favourable at times.
Why does the lamp only work once? It wasn't listed as a consumable implying it was something you could always pick up. Although understable because it would negate the checkpoint system.

reviewText:
I paid: £2.99 (Bundle price, normal price: 4.99)
I expect: 12 hours of play
I rate it 83/100
Story-driven: no (but there is one)
Demo available: yes
Worth the price. Review below.

Overall
date: I think the game will offer you a solid 10-15 hours of gameplay for a very reasonable price. I certainly enjoyed the experience more than I was expecting."\n\nI picked up Cally’s Caves 3 as part of a bundle on BundleStars.com for £2.99
recommended: and I was surprised to find that it was quite competent. Casting my eyes down the list of games that I just purchased and downloaded always fills me with buyer’s remorse.  Games which are presented as ‘indie’ titles have been so over-done that they have moved completely out of vogue
hoursPlayed: and knowing that a game has been developed by an independent entity is no longer impressive.\nThat being said
voteText: I decided to try it out anyway. I will begin with the negative points.\n\nThe game looks nice
helpfulPercent: the sprites are very crisp and clean
votesHelpful: but it lacks that last little bit of aesthetic polish. The ground and terrain is built up using tiles but as far as I can see
votesTotal: there is only one multi-tiled geographical feature and that is the soil corners. What this means is that the environment looks blocky and un-natural when it could be much richer; the best comparison that comes to mind is the mega drive Sonic games – they have floating islands that look none-square despite being made entirely of square tiles. The damage text is clearly just a basic font – arial? – and considering the frequency of its display
votesFunny: one imagines it would have been given a little extra attention. I like the fact that the game has a world map that allows you to freely teleport to checkpoints and shops
commentsCount: but the actual map looks as though it was made in mspaint
column16: which surely could have been improved with a small amount of work.\n\nThe music is very pleasant. If it was to my taste
column17: I would download the sound track quite happily. Unfortunately though
column18: the songs are not in sync with the game itself - instead
column19: they play as though it was a playlist on repeat which I found a little jarring. The controls are generally quite sharp with the exception that rolling is needlessly clunky. For some reason
column20: you have to come to a full stop before you can roll and there are two buttons depending on which way you are facing.\nThese complaints are either minor or aesthetic in nature and have almost no bearing on the gameplay. The game is extremely competent despite these flaws
column21: but it breaks no new ground. Platform games that include shooting components are tried and tested
column22: and this game brings nothing new to the table. If I hadn’t recently decided that I was actually going to play through some of the drudgery on my Steam account I probably would not have even considering installing this game. What I found in place of a boring game that failed to hold my interest was instead a game that draws together the elements that it claims to work with and polishes them to a mirror-like sheen. Nearly everything about the game is tight and it just feels great to play. No falling to your death because your foot nudged the platform corner; no weird Mario-like momentum; no throwing your character into a wall of spikes for no reason; no trying to control a crosshair on screen while also jumping from platform to platform. Everything simply works.\n\nLet not these complaints deter you
column23: however. The positive aspects of this game far outweigh the negatives. The difficulty scaling is essentially perfect
column24: for example: there is enough of a slow canter towards challenge that people unfamiliar with gaming can ease themselves into it but this is not so long as to bore those who are familiar with platforming. The deaths are frequent but fair. I did not feel as though the deaths were undeserved (with one exception) and they were infrequent enough to avoid being annoying. The exception to this is that early on in the game
column25: you rapidly learn that water is actually made of a kind of magma
column26: and stepping into it causes an instant death. There’s no reason that the game can’t just damage you and allow you to jump out
column27: but this is ultimately a minor gripe.\n\nThe game has a sense of progression about it that places it somewhere between a Mario game and a Castlevania game in terms of RPG elements. There are enough McGuffins to collect for completionists to come back and take a second look – one of them unlocks a secret level – and the weapons all have growth and upgrades for those who get a kick out of those sorts of minor rewards. Indeed
column28: just looking at how many weapons there were impressed me when I first opened a shop dialogue. To add to this
column29: there are special blocks that require you to use a specific weapon to interact with them. It was truly a mercy to find out that these weapons were actually useful in their own right. Nothing kills my enthusiasm for a weapon system than a clumsily handled switch because you are forced to use something that sucks.\n\nThe levels are laid out in such a way that you will see secrets before you have the means to obtain them. This is pretty standard
column30: but for an indie developer it is a sign that some extra thought has gone into the design of the game; something that too many indie titles are lacking. In addition
column31: there are extra game modes for once you have finished the main game which is a nice reason to pick the game back up again.\n\nOverall
column32: I think the game will offer you a solid 10-15 hours of gameplay for a very reasonable price. I certainly enjoyed the experience more than I was expecting."

reviewText:
Today, for my 200th review, I'm going to be looking at Super Metroid! For over 20 years, this game has been considered one of the all-time best, but in my opinion it... oh... wait... really?! Actually, for my 200th review, I'm going to be looking at Cally's Caves 3. Huh. This is supposed to be a momentous occasion, so I should be critiquing an important & highly-regarded game. I guess it wasn't meant to be.

Oh well.

Seriously though, Cally's Caves 3 is actually pretty decent. I haven't played either of the previous games, but I guess that isn't really important. Cally's parents have been kidnapped by a Mad Scientist. In her quest to rescue Mommy & Daddy, she jumps and shoots through dozens of levels, while putting together an arsenal to rival World War 3. There's a simplistic charm to this game that's hard to ignore. It reminds me of the kinds of videogames kids would imagine. Cally has a shotgun so now she's shooting wolves, skeletons, and bandits. Is that a giant hornet? She better blow it away with her rocket launcher. Cally triple-jumps and has a pet bear that knows kung-fu. It's aspects like these that make the tone light-hearted and amusing.

At first, the game is rather slow. The enemies are placed in locations where you can easily get away, or shoot from an advantageous position. This is mainly to counter-balance the fact that enemies take a bit of punishment before they go down. This becomes a common theme of the game. You can make the process of killing baddies more efficient with different guns, and using the sword to stun them for a brief moment. What you'll be doing more than anything else though is grinding. This is bound to put off more than a couple players, and speaking for myself, constant upgrades can be just as much a detriment as a boon for many games.

That said, I think Cally's Caves 3 works well with this system. It's similar to the weapons in the Ratchet and Clank series. While they're not as creative, the guns acquired throughout Cally's adventure, recieve substantial upgrades. Aside from shooting more powerful bullets, these guns can adopt new properties, such as a heat-seeking add-on for the rocket launcher, or a piercing effect for the blade gun. It also helps that there's a constant rate of positive reinforcement throughout the game. You're always finding new weapons, acquiring strength boosts, leveling up, or purchasing something useful. I also like that whenever a gun undergoes a major upgrade, the screen showcases the newly-kitted out weapon along with a flurry of explosions.

This is one of those games that also makes New Game+ interesting. The enemies recieve a substantial health-boost, and their numbers are bolstered due to an influx of fresh-faces. Aside from having a massive arsenal, you've likely also purchased a number of coin multipliers, so you should be able to afford the weapon mods. These mods are elemental, and can as much as double or triple the player's DPS when used with the right weapon against an enemy weak to its effects.

You probably won't notice due to the steady stream of weapon upgrades and other amusing aspects, but Cally's Caves 3 is a really easy game. There might be a couple stumbling blocks early on in the form of certain boss-fights, but after enough upgrades you'll enter a How could you ever die?" state. On one hand
recommended: because there are more than enough hardcore
voteText: one-hit-equals-death
helpfulPercent: spike-laden platformers. On the other hand
votesHelpful: becoming so overpowered in this game makes it feel menial. When you play Survival mode in this game
votesTotal: you're not worried about your life
votesFunny: you're more worried about having the patience to sit through it for so long. At least the cash rewards are pretty nice
commentsCount: and they're good for farming achievements.\n\nWhile this isn't quite the masterpiece I was hoping to write about for my 200th review
column16: I have to admit that Cally's Caves 3 is well-done. It lacks the challenge found in other contemporary platformers
column17: but it's still thoroughly compelling. It reminds me of something that would have been popular back in the shareware days. A simplistic yet charming shootemup with a nice soundtrack and a lot of content.\n\nIt's worth looking into

reviewText:
I've only played through the first zone and am headed into the second, as of writing this review.

There is a lot to like about this game, but there are loads of issues as well. I'm going to list a few of the pros+cons I've observed so far:

Pros:
Aesthetic is nice
Controls feel solid
Weapon upgrade system works well and is a lot of fun

Cons:
No analog support?
Lots of weird gameplay systems (being able to fight the first boss over and over. I used him to grind my shotgun to level 10 in about 10 minutes).
Music doesn't follow the gameplay very well (title screen music just keeps playing when you press start and is the background music for that area of the game)
Enemy AI seems really rudimentary (granted I'm early in the game so this might change) walking left/right on a platform


Its a nice little game, albeit very rough around the edges. But for 10 bucks its a decent value (though it feels like a 5 dollar game TBH).

EDIT: Apparently the version I bought was the deluxe version. The regular version wasn't available at the time I purchased it. The 6.99 price point seems pretty fair.

reviewText:
If you like platformers or great games in general, than this one is for you!
Its a great gme to play for a few minutes here and there but also can be a couple hours worth of time sunk.
Every weapon levels by just using it, changes forms, adds new variations and gets a new look.
The soundtrack is great as well and comes with the deluxe version.
The controls are very tigh except the roll mechanic you get later on is a tad wonky but nowhere near gamebreaking.
The level design is great from world to world
Tons of enemy variation as you progress although they really just move back and forth platorm to platform, but it is a platformer after all.
The first two are iOS and are worth checking out as well, i would say this is the definitive verison for Cally though

reviewText:
I can't remember where I got this game but it's awesome!
I've been playing it today and well, everything is fantastic! What's ever better, there's an android version of it too! :)
So that said here's why I like it.

PROS:
It's a simple but effective platformer, it brings back old memories of similar games.
It has a simple leveling system! (I love RPG aspects in games, no matter how simple).
You gain exp from killing, you level up. You gain more health.
Monsters get progressively harder, so my mindless run and gun tactic doesn't work so well :)
You can also find other guns (you start with a handgun and a sword) later on you get a lot more guns!
You can also LEVEL up the guns! Yes, the more you use a gun the more it levels up, morphs / changes and becomes stronger!
Boss fights! - Woo, definitely has everything a platform game has to offer!
Do I recommend this game!? HELL YES!
Will I play it over and over!? HELL YES!

Cons:
No multiplayer...
Multiplayer would be fun, both local and over the internet :)

reviewText:
While this game was a lot of fun to play, I felt that there wasn't a whole lot of challenge involved. It was definitely worth playing.

The differences between weapons, and their locations in the game presented enough of a reason to play despite the rather sparse story.

If you want the entire story, you have to play through the game twice which I'm not necessarily a fan of, but the enjoyment of the game made it less onerous to do so.

I can't wait for the next game by this team.

reviewText:
It’s somewhat shocking that the first two Cally’s Caves games never made it onto Steam – they’re only available from the iTunes Appstore and were made for mobile play only. Consequently many PC gamers may never have heard of this outstanding franchise by ZDO Games. To bring you up to speed the Cally’s Caves franchise has always represented outstanding platform gameplay with heavy does of elements from adventure and RPG games. It was with much delight when it was announced that they were going to be making the third game available on PC.

The Cally’s Caves games have always utilized intelligent retro style platformer graphics. The characters – both Cally and the other NPCs both enemies and otherwise – are all very well designed. Although the music is energizing and suits the game it becomes a bit too repetitive. The game could have been improved by having a larger soundtrack.

The game play is traditional platform style action but features a weapon upgrade similar similar to that found in the Ratchet and Clank games. As you use your weapon you will find that it gradually upgrades itself. At each upgrade level the weapon will increase damage and add effects that make the game easier to play without ever really breaking the game to the point where it feels like cheating. The biggest negative to the actual gameplay is that the enemies are damage on touch. This can be very frustrating early in the game to non-advanced players when they reach the first boss level and accidentally land on the tip of his tail which can very quickly cost the player their life and force a start over. IT makes the game to be a rhythm game at times. The most significant advantage to the gameplay in my opinion is that although there is no tutorial the game design teaches you the mechanics as you traverse through the first levels of the game. This is outstanding game and level design and is a highlight throughout the entire history of the franchise.

Another highlight for me is that the game has a metric truck load of weapons and upgrades. Finally, and definitely worth mentioning is the amount of content – good content – that makes up the game. In complete honesty not many studios release games in this genre with nearly as much content as what VDO Games put into Cally’s Caves 3. When you think you’ve completed the game it feels as though you’ve really just started. At $6.99 it represents an absolute bargain.

If you’re interested in metroidvania type platform RPGs then you absolutely should buy Cally’s Caves 3. We can only hope that VDO Games is able to port the first two games onto Steam so that we can have all three parts of the trilogy – to date – on Steam. Although Cally’s Caves 3 certainly improves upon what the first two games accomplished Steam players definitely deserve to have access to all three games on the PC platform.

Go out and buy this one.

For more reviews similar to this one and our daily giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/

Usually the character in the game explains powerups after the fact.
For example, you gain a new ability then must use it to finish the room.
THEN, in the next room he explains to you what it does.
Like, thanks for letting me know I can do what I just had to do before you told me.
Shut up and go away.

There is nothing special or standout-ish about the title but when I need to
kill some time or keep my hands busy whole listening to something I don't
mind putting this game on. Very amature and game maker template feel to it,
but its not broken and the game play is mildly fun. I would not get it unless on
sale for $1 or $2. Its def enjoyable. Just keep your expectations low.

(Devs, please don't take it personal. These are just my honest & dumb opinions as one who has played hundreds of platformers since NES. I would still like to see what you make in the future.)

reviewText:
Cally's Caves 3 is a sequel to free Cally's Caves platformers from mobiles made by yet unknown indie studio VDO Games. You play in a role of a young girl Cally, whose parents get abducted by an evil scientist and you, as other girl would do too for sure, take a gun and shoot through hordes of enemies to save your parents.

It's a platformer with focus on shooting and weapon variety. You'll be able to pick from many weapons, may it be pistols, shotguns, assault rifles, RPG launchers or laser rifles. Every weapon acts a bit differently and every weapon can be leveled up. The game strongly focuses on the fact that using your weapon will make it stronger by the time. As far as the crazy nonsense story goes, you'll also see Pokémon-like evolutions of your weapons. Congrats, your shotgun has evolved into Terminator! (But don't get your hopes high, it's just a better shotgun.)

Graphic style seems to be similar to Cally's Caves 2 with slight improvements, the sounds feels more annoying after some time. What's worth praising, is the game length, as the developer really tried to make a lot of levels to make it worth the 6,99 € price tag. You'll wander through those in metroidvania style, as levels are connected through the tunnels and you can return to any checkpoint anytime.

Conclusion:Cally's Caves 3 is not a bad platformer with a lot of content, but on its own it still didn't get rid of the freeware game feel. It may be not appealing to platformer newbies with a little raw and unpolished menu design. It can be an entertaining experience for some time but I don't think it's worth recommending with so many other great platformers in the store. This just keeps being an average game and weapon variety + upgrades (damage boosts) are not enough.


For more reviews, join Samurai Vader's Point of View group and follow my curator page, I'm always happy to see feedback about my reviews.

reviewText:
Cally's Caves 3 is a port of a mobile game to PC, but don't let that scare you away.  It's ported relatively well.  It's an action-platformer with some powerups that can be earned throughout the game to give it a sort of metroidvania-like feel.  It's not a metroidvania though, since it lacks the interconnected open world of a metroidvania.  Everything is upgradeable in this game through level ups.  Every gun, your health, your sword.  There's a constant feeling of progress throughout the game.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_lw4bHb4NT8

It's a pretty solid game.  The amount of weapons and worlds means there is a lot of content in this game.  Add in an alternate adventure or two, new game+, and a survival mode, and you've got a pretty solid investment if you enjoy the gameplay.

For me, the gameplay wasn't enough.  It felt grindy because of the nature of leveling up and constantly working toward evolving your guns.  I felt more focused on getting the next evolution than I was on completing the level, and that kinda ruined my experience.  However, the gameplay is responsive and works well, just because I didn't enjoy it doesn't mean it is bad.  If the gameplay and constantly leveling up for favorite guns looks compelling to you, you'll probably really love this game.

I have some more technical gripes.  The soundtrack sometimes feels out of place and feels like it lacks something.  The sound design leaves a LOT to be desired.  The jumping sound annoys me.  The frame rate is capped to 30, which is more obvious in a fast, high-contrast sprite game like this than it would be in some other games.  The movement through menu elements with the D-pad is capped to a certain rate, such that your input when trying to move around the menu WILL be swallowed.  None of these things by themselves are too bad, but all of them turned me off of this game.  The enemy AI is incredibly basic.

In spite of all that, it's not a bad game, hence my recommendation, but only if all of this sounds fine to you.

Key was provided by VDO Games and Dietrich Online Services.

reviewText:
Cally's Cave 3 is a quite good platformer shooter that's part of a serie of games for mobile phones.

In it, you control a blonde pigtailed girl that Rambo her way through 7 zones, finding 12 weapons with infinite ammo that you can use on all the enemies. The weapons get stronger the more you use them. She can buy several upgrades to help getting money faster or regen her health or increase the strenght of her sword.

The game feels a little crude, but it's full of content and it's quite enjoyable. I recommend.

reviewText:
A fundamentally broken game. I bought this game because the gameplay video made it look skill-based and action-packed with lots of bullets, dodging, parrying, etc. Unfortunately, the maps and damage sponginess of the enemies completely ruin that design.

Most enemies will stay on their vertical level without moving up or down. Almost every time, you'll be able to approach them, completely risk-free, from a higher or lower level and simply spam them down with your weapon of choice. The sword cause enemies to go into a full second and a half hitstun, so once you hit an enemy once, you just have to keep swinging the sword until they die. Either way you choose to unfairly dispatch the baddies, make sure to pack a lunch; it'll be a while.

Enemies have so much HP that these tactics don't feel pro" or even "cheap" - it's just tedious. Spam from a distance or stunlock up close; either way you'll be sitting there with no risk for 5-10 seconds per enemy. And there are a lot of enemies
date: and a lot of stages.\n\nI get that the enemies have so much HP so that when you get bigger
recommended: better weapons cutting through them like butter will feel great; but you're asking a lot out of your players
hoursPlayed: who have much better games sitting on their shelf they could have fun with immediately
voteText: without having to grind up weapons.\n\nSpeaking of weapons
helpfulPercent: the levelling is completely uninteresting. Weapons get more damage as you use them (very incrementally more) and occasionally 'evolve'. This sounds cool
votesHelpful: and could be if the evolutions were meaningful or changed how you used the weapon. Alas
commentsCount: or "more damage". What's the point? Why not just balance the weapons around each other so that you choose weapons based off the level
column17: or your personal preference? When you really get down to it
column18: who cares whether your shotgun does 1.00 damage per pellet or 1.05 damage? These are actual numbers from the game
column19: I'm not even exaggerating for effect.\n\nAs for the other RPG mechanic
column21: that's broken too. From the beginning one of the first things you can buy is a drop that lets you get more money; obviously this is the optimal thing to purchase
column22: since you can see that later upgrades cost hundreds of thousands of gold
column23: and enemies drop between 10-100 apiece. Unfortunately
column24: maxing out the gold-dropping multiplier takes hundreds of thousands just by itself
column25: which means that your first few hours of this game will be doing nothing but making it so that later you'll have enough gold. What's the point of cool upgrades if they're all so expensive I can't buy them without spending hours either farming gold for them
column26: or farming gold for the gold-multiplier upgrade?\n\nThe writing
column29: etc are all mediocre but that's to be expected
column30: so no points off there.\n\nAll in all
column31: a game that missed its potential by bad design. A lot of the pieces of a good game are here. Pretty decent art
column33: the controls are tight and feel right. Some of the fights I had
column34: when the level didn't allow for cheesy tactics
column35: were pretty challenging and fun. Just needed better playtesters."

reviewText: Cally's Caves is a fun game, but extremely basic. It doesn't do much to stand out from the other flood of similar indie titles that invade Steam on an hourly basis, and even though the Ratchet and Clank weapon system is fun it gets old rather quick with the otherwise basic gameplay, and becomes pretty boring. Things are far too abrupt: getting hit is abrupt, dying is abrupt, menus are abrupt, the gameplay is just... abrupt. It's not the good kind of screen-shaking-rock-fisted abruptness either, but the kind that jars you out of whatever small experience you were having. Overall, if you want a small platformer then buy this game; the price is worth the content and it's well made with no game breaking glitches that I ran into (although why is the Slime boss called Slime IV in game but the achievement is Slime III?). I think my biggest problem is that it feels like a game made for a final project of a college course, and not one to bring anything new to the platforming scene.

reviewText: This game is garbage, but whoever made it is a marketing genius. They knew that having high-res sprites in a somewhat retro style would look good in the screenshots and bag them some purchases, and they got my money so I guess it worked. But man, everything about it is so incredibly lazy and amateur and just bad, bad, bad. There's minor things which are stupid, if forgiveable, like the fact that weapon damage is placed out to two decimal points for literally no reason (why make a pistol do 1.20 damage? Wouldn't 12 make more sense and be more aesthetically pleasing?), or the way the music sometimes just stops because they were too lazy to make it loop properly, but there's also the fact that combat is ♥♥♥♥ easy and boring, and the levels are boring, and everything is completely stiff and terrible to control. Also they managed to make widescreen mode reduce both horizontal AND vertical viewspace, meaning it's got worse widescreen support than most games in the 90s. terrible game, terrible game.

reviewText:
It can be a bit hard in the beginning until you grow some levels, buy regeneration and then it gets EXTREMLY easy, grindy and controls start to annoy you to hell.

Game constantly requires you to swap weapons to progress but you've got only ONE button to cycle through 12 weapons. Missed required gun, press the button 12 times again. You're not only forced to constantly cycle through weapons but also GRIND. You don't only grind for coins, but also grind the damn mobs for achievements that get fatter and fatter with every level. You just found next power upgrade it looked a bit easier on same level, but on the next mobs simply get fatter and now you have to spend same amount of time. Weapon leveled up? Same story. And you don't get power ups every level, so mobs just get fatter. I've sent the developers to hell and from mid game started using speed hack. A bit better but nothing to drool about.

And it's EASY, playing at twice the regular speed i didn't have a lot of problems with platforming and mobs/bosses killing me. Even on New game plus". Some mobs just look a bit different and have slightly different attack

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I only played untill the third or the fourth level / segment into the house of carls level or whatever its called (the second zone).

But yea, onto the review:
I heard somewhere that a game should captivate you within the first five minutes.. but it just didnt. I tried the game over several small play sessions and this time i just gave up on it.

Pros
-Graphics
-Controls

Cons
-Music is repetitive
-Boring level design
-Boring enemies, they just walk back and forth, back and forth.
-No immunity timer when getting hit (You can run into an enemy and die in one second by losing all your health. Bad design)
-Overpowered weapons (really? You can just hit the enemies with the sword and they get stunned, so repeat that untill they die. Or level up your shotgun and blast your way through - oh wait you die if they run into you, so its better to just use the sword, unless you're standing on a platform where they can't hit you, but you can shoot them).
-Grinding (you can barely buy any upgrades from the first store if you play it somewhat normally and take your time to collect stuff, so you have to grind points)

And that's my initial impression

reviewText:
No, Sir... I don't like it.

I was hoping for a return to old Duke Nukem 2D days with this title. Something simple and approachable.

This is a mess.

The controls are weirdly off-sync. I was playing with a controller, and it felt like it was arbitrary when I used my double-jump as opposed to a regular jump. I could play this off throughout the first level, avoiding the water traps and the tempting currency to be had if a well-timed double-jump was done. The firearms were a nice touch, leveling upon use, giving an incentive to power them up instead of stun-locking everything with a melee shot.

Then I ran into the boss.

With double-jump as finicky as it was, I found myself having to repeat the boss over and over. Even if the jumps had been dead-on (and they most certainly were not), I found myself running into the exaggerated hit-box and taking damage from the creature's outstretched tail.

After several tries, I finally prevailed. It felt more like my patience was being tested as opposed to the fist-pump that I'm sure the devs were hoping to elicit from the player. After a little bit of dialogue, I was brought to the shop...

Only inside the little screen, I tried to grab a much-needed heart from a branch overhanging the door I came in from, the one that had the boss room behind.

I landed on the door.

The boss was revived, and I was put back at the start of the fight, still injured, and expected to do the fight all over.

Nope. No thanks. Done.

reviewText:
Product received for free

I have played this game in a normal run without any of the bonus areas. I know it says only 5, minutes, but that's because I was beat the game while in places without internet, so forget about that.

CC3 is an empowering jump and shoot game~ If you like doing those two things, this is well worth a run! The fundamental controls mentioned work very well throughout the entire game. The pixel art is colorful and the animation is nice and bouncy. The use of sfx is quite characteristics of the era I believe the game was trying to emulate as well. The soundtrack is alway randomly changing, which keeps the feeling of the game a focus of interest. In a technical sense, jumping-and-shooting is buy-in-large what the game is about, and it might sound as if this would get boring over the course of the many worlds in the game, but the game spaces out the new weapons just right so that by the time you've gotten tired of shooting your old gun, you've got a new toy to enjoy all over again! If anything this just goes to show that the less-is-more" school of thought on game design can work very well!

I do wish to bring up points of the design that I didn't seem to resonate with. Do keep in mind though
date: I'm in no way asking you to make any changes
recommended: but I do believe that it is important to bring up these kinds of things in a review. Since this is the third game
voteText: as I am excited to see what you'll do next.\n\n1) The inventory is not very streamline
helpfulPercent: and accessing it necessarily slows down the gameplay. Since there are only six items
votesHelpful: I would suggest simply putting them all in the initial pause menu
votesTotal: so as to make them instantly accessible.\n\n2) The boss battle design is at odds with what I am conditioned to do when fighting normal enemies. Blitz seems to be the best way to fight enemies. However
votesFunny: trying to do this against bosses has gotten me countless defeats. The bosses are instead designed on a predictable

column17: but are in a fairly good position to parry
column18: and then waiting for that long winded attack to be over such that you can move in and blast with all you have for a brief moment that the enemy is vulnerable. In theory this difference is interesting
column19: but I just wanted to point out
column20: that all of my encounters with normal enemies has trained me to fight a completely different way
column21: and boss battles betray the logic that I have been conditioned to use in combat.\n\n3) The fundamentals are the best option. The game will grant you a bunch of abilities
column25: but none of them seem to be viable options in the middle of combat. I found myself a more adequate player when I did nothing but focus on jumping and shooting with the occasional sword slash
column26: rather than try to manage and think about all my options.\n\nMy suggestion has to do with both of the 2 mentioned above. I think my main issue with the combat is that I have no control over the enemies. Or rather: I have little to no idea what the enemies are going to do
column27: and when they are going to do that
column28: and this fundamentally makes reaction based play a bad option. Let me give you an example of the opposite
column29: as it appeared twice in the game. There is a point in the game where you have "control" over the Balding Eagle
column30: by being able to determine where he will crash into the ground. There is also a similar "control" that you have over the queen bee. This
column32: as it make it to where there is a well telegraphed amount of information that I can use for formulate a fun strategy against the enemy. In contrast
column33: I often found the behavior of the Knife Bandit
column35: and the Bazooka Hulks to be unpredictable. Sometimes they would pace back-and-forth
column36: sometimes they would turn toward me
column37: and they would attack without warning
column38: sometimes doing so while still moving forward. My suggestion here
column39: would be two things. I think that reaction and strategy can be encouraged if the enemies are designed with attacks that are more telegraphed
column40: a kind of visual cue to let the player know that an attack is coming.\n\nI do have one additional moment of confusion about the enemies. The bazooka hulks shoot green rockets at you and you cannot parry them. When I fought Melvin
column41: and saw him shooting green rockets at me

column43: there is a glitch where you can perform a "wave dash" by hitting roll and then mashing the direction forward

column50: 4) mentally figure out which button you have to press to roll
column51: because there is one for each direction 5) press that button to roll.\n\nIndeed
column52: I would oft find myself being chased down by skeletons where I only want to roll back to get behind them
column53: but never have enough time to actually input it
column54: usually instead getting me both run down and hit by a projectile.\n\nMy suggestion is this: simplify roll to be a single button
column55: and have it to where you are allowed to roll both forward
column57: while maintaining the direction you are pressing. The controls for this would work like this:\n1) if you have a neutral standing position
column58: then you will roll backwards.\n2) If you are running
column59: you will roll in the direction you are running.\n\nThe result is that it should make rolling a much more reliable option in the middle of combat
column60: and if back-roll maintains the direction you are facing
column61: it could make for some very cool scenarios where in being chased by an enemy
column62:
you can just boost behind them while giving them a scattershot to the back.

--------------------------------------------------

There is one additional thing I have to mention that confused me. The story
column64: leaves a bit too much to the imagination for someone who isn't familiar with the CC franchise. I'm talking about the little things
column66: I don't understand what  Herbert's motive is for kidnapping Cally's Parents
column67: or the significance of some of the bosses
column68: that seem to be something that Cally is familiar with
column69: but I am not. I am told that there is some additional explanation for the story by Robin and Melvin if you go out of your way to do things more than the main game. But clearing the game vinella on my first run
column70: left a lot of questions in the air for me.\n\nBut
column71: being the student of art that I am
column72:
I had to try to come up with something to make sense of it all. So here is the theory I came up with.

*Spoilers ahead*
*Spoilers ahead*
*Spoilers ahead*
*Spoilers ahead*

Herbert is interesting in that he seems to have a soft spot for Cally in addition to Rupert.

The Rupert soft-spot is takes the form of that in the final level
column74: it is shown that there are two assets repeating the cave
column75: a self-portrait bust statue of Herbert
column76: and a family photograph. What this says to me is that there are 2 things that Herbert is willing to admit that have meaning to him
column77: himself and Rupert.\n\nAs for his fondness for Cally. The first thing is that he talks at Cally as if she doesn't mean anything to her
column78: or that she is a swor"
